Legion of Honor.name: Legion of Honor
reviews:
If you go on the first Tuesday of the month, it is free admission (otherwise $15 adults; free under 18 yrs) to the general collections. A nice art museum of varied artworks in a great setting overlooking the GG Bridge. Love the grandiose architecture as you approach the Beaux-arts building with "The Thinker" in the centre of the inner Courtyard. Car parking is limited so get there before late morning or take the bus (#18). If you do buy the general admission ticket, you can get into the de Young Art Museum for free on the same day (which is in another beautiful location: Golden Gate Park).
Show less
Broad and varied collection of art

The Palace of Legion of Honor Museum contains artwork from many centuries, styles, artists and genres (Rodin, Monet, religious art, David, Vuillard, Boucher, El Greco, etc.). We weren't able to spend more than 2 hours today but if you like art, you could definitely spend an entire day. The rooms are well curated and display the works nicely. Also, the room dedicated to "Vertigo" was a cute touch.
Show less

Found this museum on TripAdvisor. Great experience and the Casonova exhibit was worth the visit alone! Using his life and travels as the backdrop for exploring European art of the day was intriguing and highly engaging. Going on the docent led tour is a must... you learn so much more.
Show less

This was a gem of a visit. We arrived early and were joined buy local joggers. The area provides great views of the city and the Goldern gate bridge. There is a gold course there too. If you drive on you can get a great view of the GGB along with benches to sit on, Was a bit cold in Feb.
Show less

In the middle of SF's 3 par public (?) golf course , a page out of history. A meeting point for some running groups (Like the hash house harriers -Gypsies ) , entry for a heck of a SF picturesque run.

Get the back story of why the Museum was built....the setting is lovely in the western edge of the city overlooking the Pacific - the Classical Architecture is satisfyingly wonderful....the interior spaces are beautiful, and, for a Museum if functions very well...Saw the Rodin/Klimpt show....Very well done!!
Show less
Free First Tueday of the Month

The LoH has a nice collection, especially of European fine art. The highlight for me was The Russian Bride's Attire by Konstantin Makovsky, a must-see in its details, its color, and its depiction of human life.

This was a major disappointment. First, the parking situation is ridiculous. We had to park three blocks away and walk UPHILL in the street for most of the journey. No parking structure?? For what they charge they could build a new museum I think. The upcharge for the current special exhibit was out of line for the quality of the art. There is at least one Rodin in every major museum in the world and these were not exceptional. Also, I've seen better Klimts in free museums. If this is standard, Legion of Honor is giving San Fran a black eye.
Show less

I stumbled upon this wonderful museum and glad I did. I walked by while hiking Lands End. My biggest concern is the cost. A very expensive museum, especially if you want to see any special exhibitions.
A Colorful stroll with Klimt and Rodin. A day exhibit at the Legion of Honor in San Francisco.

It's not everyday, you get to stroll the Legion of Honor in San Francisco. But, if you have the chance, I suggest you take your rent a car or the Clement Street bus, Geary Street bus, or California Street bus... and walk a few blocks to this amazing Museum. It's located on a beautiful golf course that overlooks the City and faces the Golden Gate Bridge. Do you want a little San Francisco history and romance in the afternoon? This is a beautiful place to take your special person or your mom & dad when they come visit. This building is elegant and the people that work there are so helpful and passionate about art. It's not uncommon to spend the whole day here, walking around, exploring this the beautiful area. Want to paint? Hear jazz? Take breathtaking selfies with your selfish stick, lol? Give yourself some much needed, eye candy, stimulation, and pleasure. Spend a day all the way out in the Avenues, at lands end, in the Legion of Honor San Francisco.

Go for a Special Exhibition; Visit the Park

I came for the Klimt show, which is ending. This museum has interesting special exhibitions. The regular collection is of mixed quality, and worth sweeping through once. The park is far more attractive and has better views than Golden Gate Park.
Some of the best scenery around to add to the Museum

We belong to the Museum but really like the area around it. If you can find a day especially during the week to go, parking is available and you are not inundated with folks. The walk along the coastal path is also well worth it. Stunning views of the bay and all that has to offer. Even with the crowds everything moves briskly along. When you add in the exhibits a five star place.
Show less

Although I'm not an art aficionado, I enjoyed our Legion of Honor visit more than I expected to. I went with my daughter, a German-French major who spent three years working as an English-language teaching assistant in Europe, one in France and two in Austria. When she heard that the Legion of Honor was hosting a Klimt-Rodin exhibition, she chose this as one of the stops on our San Francisco trip in early January. As I write this, the exhibition has left, but my memories of our enjoyable time viewing it remain.

I was impressed with the quality of the art on display throughout the museum as well as the arrangement of it, which allowed many people to move through the rooms without feeling overly crowded. The Legion of Honor building is a work of art in itself that lends itself to numerous photographs. The museum store is a treasure trove of items that would make great gifts for others--or for oneself.

My daughter and I spent a couple of enjoyable hours at the museum, but if you're an avid art lover, I'd recommend allowing several hours for your visit to give you time to savor your experience.
Show less

The building's architecture makes a great photo, and with ticket prices at USD 15 for general admissions, the art pieces (and actual mummies) available for viewing were better than what I expected.

Tip: Try not to bring a backpack as they will ask for you to check it in.
Show less
Great to visit - but check what is on display
If you have time check to see what is on display as the venue does change. Great place to spend time on a rainy day . There is a nice restaurant inside for lunch.

I always enjoy visiting the Legion of Honor. We couldn't get tickets to the Rodin & Klimt exhibit as it was sold out on the day. But we and visit galleries that had part of the permanent collection. The building and the grounds are also very interesting.
Show less

Went to visit the Rodin & Klimpt special exhibit. Well worth the trip! Excellent collection, nice commentaries, learned quite a bit. Nice gift shop and lovely restaurant with view for a coffee or lunch.

This museum is set at the top of a hill with views of the Golden Gate Bridge. The museum was featuring an exhibition of Klimt and Rodin. The permanent collection is also impressive. Many great photo opportunities.

The setting for this museum is gorgeous. Allow yourself time to walk around, You can walk down to the beach. The museum had a lovely collection of art. I did not know about this museum until I heard about the Klimt/Rodin exhibit.
As they had Klimt's name first we expected more works by him. We were disappointed to find less of him and much more of Rodin sculpture. For the $30 entrance fee it was really not worth the price!

We went to this museum to see the "Klimt & Rodin" exhibition and stayed on to look through all the galleries. The exhibition, which ends Jan. 28, 2018, proved to be heavy on Rodin, which was a disappointment for me. I've been to the Rodin Museum in Paris many times and explored the one in Philadelphia but have seen only a small number of Klimt's paintings. Many of the relatively few in the exhibition are unfinished, sketches or minor works.

But for those who have not seen Rodin sculpture up-close and personal or would like to see more, the exhibition presents a nice array. And the museum itself has an outstanding collection of Rodin's work. One of the cast bronzes of his "The Thinker" is on a pedestal in the entry courtyard, which costs nothing to visit. The other major collections focus on ancient and European art, which hold little interest for me. Gallery 19 displays Impressionism and Post-Impressionism works, but I saw nothing noteworthy here.

We stopped in the museum's cafe for snacks and ate them on a lovely patio. There is also a nice gift shop.

The museum mostly appeals to me, however, for its architecture and location. The Beaux-Arts building is patterned after the Palais de la Legion d'Honneur in Paris. It sits on a hill in Lincoln Park with stunning views of the Pacific Ocean and Golden Gate Bridge. We came by the #1 bus from Downtown, getting off at 32nd Avenue and Clement Street, walking uphill for about 10 minutes to reach the museum. For those driving, there is a small parking lot directly across from the building.

Our recent visit to this museum was enjoyable. Much of the art is religious. Not my personal favorite although we appreciated it. Set near the Presidio, Lands End and Baker Beach with awesome views of the GGBridge.... this beautiful area offers much to see and do.
Admission is inexpensive and includes admission to the De Young in GGPark. Lots to see and do.

Excellent temporary art exhibits, as well as permanent exhibits. It has a large theater for live performances, and a room where organ concerts are given on Sundays. There's a good restaurant with in and outdoor seating, and 2 gift shops.
Have always loved their special exhibits. Stable collection wonderful

We have been to the Legion of Honor many times for special exhibits. It never fails to impress. They have a permanent collection of Rodan's worth seeing. Nice, but expensive cafe. Lovely grounds. Tough parking if you are disabled.
Value of the museum vs price, not worth

We really didn’t like this museum, even they have a couple of temporary exhibitions, the collections are very limited . The price was the same as SFMOM, And of course is a different museum , but nothing to do. I really don’t recommend you to send your time here. If you are in the area go to the park. Great views

Check the schedule and definitely go. The permanent exhibit is amazing but they often have special exhibits. The dining room at the Museum is great for a nice lunch with many healthy choices.

We went here during the night time as we were not able to see it during the day. It was still a lovely night to see the thinking man. I visited the Legion of Honor seven years ago and it still looks the same.

Rodin has many sculptures here and the additional artwork and collections are vastly interesting and pleasing to the eye. The grounds are peaceful and inviting, nice restaurant, cute little gift shop. Go enjoy!
Small enough to take in all the art in a day!

This is a beautiful building in a beautiful location with beautiful art! When we arrived their was ample parking at the museum as well as parking available along the adjoining road up to the museum.

General admission gets you into their permanent gallery only. It is a very pleasant way to spend a half day or even an hour or two.

If you are lucky enough to be in San Francisco while this exhibit is in place, don't miss it. The sculpture and paintings are glorious.

Went to see Rodin/Klimt exhibition. Was disappointed that there wasn't very many of Klimt's work displayed. The museum itself is really nice, but it is a bit small. It costed $25 to see Rodin/Klimt. However, this fee doesn't include the exhibition on Greek gods that was downstairs. You would have to pay a separate fee to see it. The perimeter around the museum is gorgeous.

Iconic museum with great special exhibits!

This is my favorite fine art museum in San Francisco. I mean, the De Young is just about the only other one, but this one is just so beautiful inside and out!

They always have such an interesting permanent collection as well as very cool special exhibitions.

Parking is kind of a pain, you can spend quite a few minutes looking around for a space.
Show less

The Rodin and Klimt exhibit was excellent ($30 admission) - what a thrill to see so many Klimt's together and become aware of the connections between these arists! The museum itself is not very big, so you can see it all fairly quickly. The cafe is very pleasant. The shop contains a smaller selection of items than the deYoung shop. Free parking right in front was no problem.
Show less
Rodin and Gustav Klimt in the US!

Hubs and I got our tickets online well before our Saturday visit. We arrived 15 minutes prior to opening, and we had plenty of close-in free parking to choose from.

The exhibits did not disappoint. The descriptions next to each piece gave added depth to our enjoyment.

We spent a solid 2 hours here. Including a visit to both gift shops. Nice!

When we were leaving, there was a long line to get in, and parking was scarce.

Motto: arrive early to avoid crowds.

I went to the museum for the Klimt and Rodin exhibition and enjoyed the beauty of the building as well.The building is in a beautiful location with views of San Francisco Bay.
Regal Spot Looking out over the Pacific
We visited this regal spot overlooking the Pacific. Listened to two talks inside and toured the special exhibits. Had a lovely little lunch.
Lots of pretty things to see
A couple of the big exhibits cost extra, and we only had a couple hours so we skipped those. There were plenty of beautiful things to see.

I love the variety of art in this museum! The building itself is architecturally pleasing. My favorite pieces are the impressionist and post impressionist pieces; however, I found something I liked in each room. Highly recommend!
This is a very beautiful setting; the building is gorgeous and the grounds are very peaceful; there's a nice view of the GG Bridge in the distance. I enjoyed the Matisse exhibit immensely.

The Klimt show is small, poorly lit, and expensive ($30/person). Klimt is one of my favorite artists and I was sorry to see so few finished paintings. This show isn't worth the crowds and the cost.
The location of the Legion of Honor is fantastic. Go there for the views of the bay but skip this show.

My family has many fine artists in it, and many who enjoy art, but I am not an art lover. I do however, appreciate a good presentation. The Klemp and Rodan exhibit Are such an exhibit. If you love art and sculptures please come here
Beautiful art museum in Lincoln Park

This is a beautiful museum. Parking is limited. When you arrive, don’t just go in. Explore the surroundings. There is a short walk that will take you to a Holocaust Memorial, a Japanese Memorial and great views of the Golden Gate Bridge. Inside the museum, you will find the works of many masters as part of the permanent collection. I went for the special exhibits. Currently, there are two. One is Klimt and Rodin, two of my personal favorites. These two artists were contemporaries, both rebels of their time, and both created very sensual art. The other exhibit is Color of the Gods. FABULOUS!!! We are used to seeing the sculptures of the Greeks and Romans as beautiful white marble. But those beautiful white marbles were not seen by the Greeks and Romans. What they saw were brightly painted marble. This exhibit focuses on recreating those colorful sculptures based on sophisticated techniques and research. My friend and I spent 5 hours at the museum. We spent about an hour at each special exhibit. We took the docent tour (45 minutes) of the antiquities exhibit. There is no docent tour of Klimt and Rodin, but there was a 45 minute lecture. We attended that. We spent about half an hour having lunch and we spent about an hour exploring the permanent exhibit. We spent maybe a half hour walking around Lincoln Park. A wonderful day!

Beautiful museum in a scenic location
Went to see the Klimt\Rodin exhibit last week and enjoyed touring more of the museum afterward. A bit pricey for the size of the exhibit, but worth it if you're a fan of Klimt or Rodin.

This wonderful museum has a bit to please everyone. If you like Rodins then this is a great place to see a variety of his work. Many fantastic paintings and tapestries. And the cafe is a good place to grab a light lunch.
Great place to spend a Sunday afternoon.

We went for the Klimt and Rodin exhibits but loved the museum's general collection equally as well. The setting, above the Presidio, overlooking San Francisco's Golden Gate, is spectacular. Be sure to stay for the weekend organ concert. The entire experience is absolutely delightful.

We went to see the recent Klimt/Rodin special exhibition, as well as The Gods of Polychrome. This is a lovely museum in general, but in my opinion both special showings fell flat. The Klimpts were scarce and the polychrome thing was just a bunch of reproductions. The place was packed so there was little opportunity to enjoy what was there. 35 dollars a person is just way way way too much. I actually felt betrayed. My fair city has found yet another way to exclude all but the well off. Very disheartening!

Beaux Arts Elegance Combined with Outstanding Exhibits Make the Palace Irresistible

The setting is at the top of a hill whose base touches San Francisco Bay. The museum overlooks the bay, Golden Gate Bridge, and wooded Marin County on the opposite shore. In short, it's spectacular. The Legion of Honor is beautiful all by itself, with a huge fountain, green lawn and a marble and stone courtyard (embellished by a bronze of 'The Thinker' by Auguste Rodin) leading to the entrance of the building. Inside the rooms immediately past the ticket area are devoted to the sculptures and art of Rodin. There are Special exhibits are offered both on the ground floor level and downstairs. There is a very good cafe downstairs, also, as well as exhibit cases in the hall way showing smaller sculptures and artifacts.
I visited the museum a week ago and, although I have been there many times over the years, I felt the same rush I always do. The beautiful surroundings and the high quality of the collection are just amazing.
Show less
Went for the Klimt exhibit, and loved seeing the paintings up close. The depth and colors are beyond what you can imagine if you have only seen pictures.

You'll love this museum with innovative employees who know how to put together interesting special exhibits. The current exhibit combines Klimt's gorgeous paintings with his good buddy Rodin's drawings and sculptures, some of which are part of the permanent collection. The 4 star view of San Francisco from Lincoln Park where the museum is situated will take your breath away. What a great way to spend a Sunday morning.

Phenomenal and incredible opportunity to see this exhibit. Words cannot express the simultaneous joy of life and sense of mortality I experienced. You have to go!!!
Enjoy the view, but also go inside

This is far out in the western reaches of the City, but worth a trip. We took a Number One bus from downtown (Sacramento and Montgomery) which slowly proceeds over half a dozen hills and through a variety of neighborhoods. Then you transfer to a nearby Number 38, and in two minutes you'll be up at the Legion of Honor. Great views of the distant Golden Gate Bridge and what looks like a particularly good golf course. The Legion of Honor is so stately that Chinese brides like to have their wedding portraits taken there. Inside the permanent collection is good, and there are often outstanding special exhibits. Good cafe with nice food and reasonable prices. Visiting this place is a great way to spend a peaceful afternoon in San Francisco. Turn off your cell phone when you come here, and the whole experience will feel like a quiet sojourn in a slower, earlier era.

The best little museum in san Francisco!
Make sure to use the headsets to get the full experience! The cafe is lovely with delicious options for lunch
Great museum with a fabulous view

We went to the Gustav Klimt exhibit at the Legion of Honor in San Fransisco and had a great lunch at the museum cafe. They have a lot of great permanent exhibits as well. The view of the San Francisco harbor is amazing.
Good museum in a beautiful location

My wife and I spent a couple of hours here, which meant we took our time and skipped nothing. The museum is not large, and substantial gallery space was taken up by two special exhibitions that required additional tickets. The museum was nicely laid out, and the building itself is beautiful. The nicest part may be the setting, though, with spectacular views from a perch atop the hill. Since enjoying this museum didn’t take the time we allotted, we decided to take advantage of the admission also getting us in to the de Young, which I’ll review separately. I highly recommend carving out time to take in both, as together they add up to a whole as compared to other major city’s museums.

The Legion of Honor commands great view of the city of San Francisco and the Golden Gate Bridge. It's collection of Western Art ranges from antiquity to the late 20th century and provides a great overview of art across the ages as well as across media. Their paintings and ceramics are first rate; but unless you've been to his Museum in Paris, their Rodin sculptures are worth the price of admission.

Though I sort of liked the special exhibit of Rodin and Klimke, who seem to have been contemporaries united by common vision of sensuality in their work, it was their other exhibit -- entitled Gods in Color -- that made me go wow.

Years ago, I read about how Ancient Greek and Roman sculptures were painted; but this exhibit not only showed what their painted works looked like (loud and brightly colorful) but also provided background on the historical references to their use of color and explained how chemical and spectographic analyses were used to reconstruct the coloration of their statues.

The first two picture that I've attached are of the same bas relief--the first is bathed in white and relies on shadow for its effects and the second pops out it figures through the use of color. The third and fourth pictures are of a fully painted archer and a partly painted goddess; both seemed to have in the Acropolis. Very interesting.

From the structure itself to the statues on the grounds, the is was a very enjoyable stop during our stay in San Francisco. Great views as well.
Excellent permanent collection and superb exhibitions
This museum is a treasure for S.F. Location is breathtaking. Will be surprised by the quality of art and the choice of rotating exhibitions.
Grand building in a brilliant position and good exhibitions

I visited with friends who live close by and knew there was the Klimt and Rodin exhibition on. The building is not a typical museum by design but the entrance area is cool with its many columns and open space.
The exhibition was good and some of the Klimt portraits were wonderful especially the pastels and sketches as well as the more colourful bright paintings one tends to recall about this artist.
The Rodin sculptures are wonderfully detailed - you want to touch them and imagine how his models kept their positions.
We had no time to roam around all the other rooms but it is well worth a visit. Some good books and jewellery in the shop.
The cafe was expensive for the food we ate but with the dollar/sterling exchange rate being what it is, most cafe or restaurant fare is pricey these days.

lovely way to pass a day well

I took a dear international friend to the Degas and The French Millinery Trade exhibit in September. It was delightful as was the rest of the museum's exhibits. The Legion of Honor is located in Golden Gate Park and walking around the site and driving out on the north coastal road are also treats. For a lovely outing in SF, especially for art enthusiasts, this was a great day.

Really fine collection of works. Some might find it pricey, but consider the provenance and the artworks themselves. We found it a lovely experience.
The Legion never fails to have a quality show

Coming to the Legion after the DeYoung Summer of Love was pretty refreshing. The permanent exhibitions and the rotating new shows keeps me going back. Parking is my only issue. Food is good in their dining area as is the gift shop.
Well worth a visit - stay away from the extortionist café

I visited in August 2017.

The Legion of Honor has a wonderful permanent collection, which was my reason for being their. I also attended the "Degas, Impressionism, and the Paris Millinery Trade" exhibition, which was not worth it! I loved the painting and sculpture collection, which I definitely recommend. There were also two negatives: (i) the Café is one of the most shockingly overprices museum cafés that I have ever been in. I found it quite shameful, in fact. The problem is: there are no other eating options nearby, which is why the museum can extort visitors in thsi way. A second negative is that, failing having your own car, a taxi is the only option to get to the museum. The bus is simply too impractical. As a foreigner, getting a taxi back is not that easy, however, numbers are available at reception, although they "cannot call you back" if you are using a foreign telephone number.

The café extortion aside, definitely worth a visit.

Great Collection, Wish We Could Have Seen the Whole Thing

This is an art museum with great works, and is small enough to see in one day. The highlight was a discussion by a docent of the Egyptian mummies and how they were made. She was perhaps the best informed docent in any museum that I can remember. Other highlights are the Rubens, Rembrandt and El Greco paintings and the porcelain collection. Unfortunately, the Rodin sculptures were moved to a special exhibit which we passed up because it was grossly overpriced. And since the English paintings were in a room next to the special exhibit, they were off limits to regular viewers even though not part of the special exhibit. How do you explain that?

Nice and cozy museum with beautiful scenery!

A nice little cozy museum located in one of the most beautiful sites of the city! Very clean everywhere! Beautiful and clean restroom decorated with nice fresh-flower vases is pretty and relaxing. The room with a beautiful collection of porcelain pieces is a must-see, and my favorite.

Modelled after the French Pavilion of the Pan-Pacific American International Exhibition, this elegant building houses classic art and some BLOCK-BUSTER shows. Scenic overlook is jaw=-dropping
its a picture perfect location built amidst sea or creek area of SFO and its huge. Right across this monument one can see rest of SFO city.
This is a wonderful museum in a fantastic location. Check for the current featured instalation. Give yourself at least 3 hours.
Stiff museum with basic art history exhibition

But interesting Rodin vs Klimt exhibition when we were there. Café also decent - but overpriced. Shop - pale. Probably this is an Excellent art history training museum for SF-people, in a stiff context.
Great place for a museum - so near the cliff views. Rodin and klimt exhibition was well worth the trip - some great and inspiring works from these classics.
in case you are right now in san francisco you shouldn't miss the actual shows of rodin and klimt and on top the spectacular show 'gods of color'!

Terrible staff - thus the 2 star rating. Not helpful - i felt as though I was part of a grade school field trip.

The exhibit was wonderful! The ticket price is extreme for the size of the museum, and must be purchased to view only the special exhibit.

Small museum with a great collection

Do you avoid museums because they take too long? The Legion of Honor is a relatively small museum with an amazing collection that you can see in an hour (or two or three depending on your level of interest). And the setting is spectacular.

Lovely location and decent permanent collection but $35 is pricey for admission to the special exhibitions. Klimt Rodin is a decent mid-sized Klimt show padded out, in my opinion, with a tenuous connection to another of the West Coast's large collection of Rodin's works.

I have been coming here for a few years since I am a member but this is my first review. The setting of this intimate museum is almost surreal, on a clear day the view is spectacular. In the morning there is a lot less crowd and you don't have to elbow your way through just to see the artworks up close. The cafeteria downstairs serves surprisingly good food and coffee. It's more convenient to take Muni bus as it stops right out front.

Great special exhibition Klimt and Rodin

My sister and I had a great time here. She joined the museum and took me to the exhibition for my birthday. What a treat. The docent was really funny and informative. It is a nice size museum, not too big. We went for a lovely walk to Lands End before our entry time and had a delicious quiche lunch at the museum cafe. Their museum shop is also great. I never buy anything and I ended up cramming two books into my carry on.

The museum is in a beautiful location. If you have a chance take the hike nearby for some postcard quality photos of the Golden Gate Bridge. The museum has some amazing pieces but what I loved was the ability to see and learn about artists new to me. I love smaller museums because you get to spend more time with a piece...that being said my only complaint were the large amounts of school children running around the museum. If their teachers and chaperones can't control them then they should be reprimanded by the staff. There were kids running in the galleries and they were extremely loud. The highlight of my trip was the tour by Chaney. She was very good and she even added a few pieces not normally on the tour because I liked them.

Great museum, very dangerous parking lot for break-ins

Wonderful shows at this museum, but average amount of cars broken into in the parking lot, both in front and on the side of the museum, is 2 -3 per day (just ask the museum staff)! People are watching when you put your valuables in your trunk and will smash your windows and steal them. Take everything inside to the free coat check and leave it there!

The museum is located in a beautiful setting in San Francisco and, for us, was one of the major highlights of our visit. We went on a Saturday and were a bit overwhelmed by the admission price - $30 per person and then another $15 to see a special exhibit. The museum itself has a fairly reasonable collection for its size -- it is not a very large space. I am not sure I would pay these prices to go back into the museum, but, I would go back to this location, park, and enjoy the scenery from this part of San Francisco.

Came here for the Teotihuacan exhibit. Very well organized and curated. Our cudos to the docent, Leopoldo Villela.

Our family of five visited the museum for the Klimt exhibit, but found all of the artwork outstanding. Not a particularly huge museum, very do-able in a half-day to a day's visit. Just a very well-run operation, period. We were even impressed with the wonderful food and ambience of the café on the lower level. We highly recommend a visit.

All museums house collections, exhibitions and a museum store. If you truly enjoy paying the admission fee to view amazing art then by all means this museum was exhibiting works by Klimt when I visited this past week.

What is truly unique and beautiful about Legion of Honor, LOH, is the location. It may seems odd to some that there is a golf course surrounding LOH but once you truly take a look around you will see nature and the beauty of everything.

Passing the arched entrance you find Rodin greeting you and all of a sudden you are now enclosed in pillars. There really are not, in my case, words to describe what visiting LOH makes you feel. My wife and I happened to walk here from the pacific heights neighborhood but LOH is easily accessible via MUNI Bus or even by cab, car, bike, whatever.

My main reason for making the trip to LOH was because it was featured in Hitchcock's film "Vertigo". Not having visited the museum inside I felt the long walk was worth it. We even saw huge crows wandering the golf course.

For those looking to visit "monuments" of sorts this is one place to visit.

We didn't know what to expect at the Legion of Honor museum since we were between major art shows but decided to check it out nonetheless. We're glad we did. First, it's in a beautiful setting so just walking outside and around its beautiful columns (where a photoshoot of ballerinas was taking place when we were visiting) was a treat in itself. Just viewing the Golden Gate Bridge from the overlook was wonderful.
Inside, the collection (excluding any major exhibition) was small but lovely and all very engaging.
It was an afternoon well spent.

Excellent special collection: Klimt and Rodin
We say the Klimt and Rodin exhibit — excellent. Crowded though and noisy. The setting for this museum is wonderful, worth even a brief visit for that alone and to contemplate Rodin’s thinker.
Klimt and Rodin - Go See It

The museum kindly brought together two of my favorite artists with the juxtaposition of their work well done and interesting. Admission also includes access to the general exhibition which is a weird but wonderful collection of art and artifacts from around the world that I found very enjoyable as it was a glimpse of many schools and influences without being overwhelming. You need to keep your eye out for treasures in every room!

The staff were very friendly and helpful and more than one docent saw my interest in something and talked to me about it, telling me more than what was on the plaque or audio guide.

The Legion of Honor is a bit off the beaten path but I enjoyed the morning ride on the #1 bus and walk around Lincoln Park. This is the only reason for the four stars - it takes some persistence to get there. But worth it and I recommend you take the time to visit while in the City.

Great location. Great museum Klimt and Rodin opened oct 15. Gods in color ones soon

Legion of Honor Is the sole venue for Klimt and Rodin. Definitely worth a visit for the special exhibit, well displayed permanent collection of European art, fantastic location with great bay views and a great cafe.
It is one of two SF city Fine Art Museums. Your admission to the Legion includes a visit to the permanent collection of the De Young on the same day.

We attended the Legion of Honor on a Friday in September. It was foggy driving in via the Golden Gate, and the cool breezes saved us from the dry Sacramento heat. On the agenda was a showing of Degas, Impressionism, and the Paris Millinery Trade. Featuring ~40 Impressionist paintings and pastels by Degas (many never before exhibited in the United States), Renoir, Manet, Mary Cassatt, Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec and more. There were also 40 well-preserved examples of period hats, some adorned with feathers, lace, and flowers on display throughout the exhibit.
Needless to say, we really enjoyed the full experience!
Since it was not a Saturday or Sunday, there were not as many visitors roaming about. We were able to find parking near the Museum quite easily. The price of the show was reasonable ($28), and the layout and presentation was impeccable!
Being fans of the Hitchcock film, Vertigo, we were also elated to finally see where part of it was filmed...right here at the Legion of Honor!
Afterwards, we were able to walk the full length of the Museum, and see all of the other exhibits and collections as well. Wow! One of our favorite rooms was Salon Doré, the 18th Century Period Room re-creation from the Hôtel de La Trémoille. It is a lot to take in, so be sure to give yourself plenty of time to enjoy it, and definitely take a stroll around the grounds for a bit too. Do not miss this opportunity!

The Legion of Honor is an excellent art museum by any standards, but having been in dozens of the best art museums in the world, the collection itself, although quite nice, is not what impressed me most. It is located in a beautiful area called Lincoln Park and my wife and I also walked through Golden Gate Park to get there. Walking home we took a trail along the Pacific coast and stopped by the 19th century ruins of the Sutro Baths. The objective of that day's adventure in San Francisco was to see the artwork, but the natural beauty that we encountered coming and going made it a particularly exceptional day. I had been to the DeYoung Art Museum on a previous visit to the city. If I were to be given a choice of which museum to visit, I'd choose the Legion of Honor for its generally older artwork (although mixed in with contemporary art) over the more modern DeYoung, but both are worthwhile. Both buildings are quite interesting architecturally as well, and in entirely different ways.

The Legion of Honor is set high on a ridge in the northeast section of San Francisco. It is truly a destination and not something you just walk by on a city street. The museum building is modeled after the Legion of Honor in France and houses excellent exhibits of its collection - including great Rodin sculptures - as well as special exhibits. We visited the exhibit of Monet: the Early Years, which drew paintings from museums all over the world. It was interesting only in that it showed what he did before he did his grand paintings of water lillies, etc. We made the mistake of going on a Saturday - big crowds. They try to manage the crowds with timed entrances, but standing two or three deep is not the way to view great art. Next time, I will visit this out of the way gem on a weekday.

While I was greatly impressed with the Monet collection, and was very happy to see
his "early works," I was not impressed with the staff and their handling of the
crowds. I came away with the definite feeling that the deYoung Museum is
much better able to handle exhibits by famous artists, with the accompanying
large turnout. I was told that I was "lucky" to be able to get into the exhibit,
but lucky was not how I felt. I have a membership to both of the Fine Arts
museums, and have always enjoyed visiting the deYoung. However, the
staff at the Legion of Honor seemed to have little knowledge of something
called "customer satisfaction." I was not the only one to feel that way.
Another woman who was waiting to get into the exhibit while I was, told
me (in relation to the audio guides, which required "cash" only), that she
had been dropped off by a family member, and did not have any cash.
Subsequently, she had to call the family member, and request that he
return to the art museum. In the meantime, a staff member had told her
that she could, after all, use a credit card.
This exhibit was the Legion's chance to attract many new members, but
I hope that if another "famous" artist is invited to the Legion, the staff will
find ways to be more polite and more welcoming.

Fine arts gift from Alma Spreckles to San Francisco

In addition to being located in the very charming Lincoln Park corner of San Francisco, the building is a full-scale replica, by George Applegarth and H. Guillaume, of the French Pavilion at the 1915 Panama–Pacific International Exposition; which in turn, was a three-quarter-scale version of the Palais de la Légion d'Honneur also known as the Hôtel de Salm in Paris, by Pierre Rousseau in 1782. Today it's part of the Fine Arts Museum of SF. We were able to walk in and buy tickets for the Monet: The Early Years exhibit at the De Young, which was tremendous. Afterwards, we viewed the collection of Rodin sculptures which Mrs. Spreckles had collected in her lifetime. The setting is tremendous and the views of the Golden Gate Bridge from the grounds is amazing. The Palace of the Legion of Honor was the western terminus of the Lincoln Highway, the first improved road for automobiles across the U.S., which originated in Times Square, New York! Be sure to find the gorgeous Lincoln Park steps at the corner of California Street at Outer Richmond. The 52-step path looks as though someone rolled a colorful tile rug down its jagged slope! We walked from Nob Hill (about 10 miles R/T), but public busses run all the way to the Legion of Honor, down California. You can also save money on admission to the art exhibits, from destinationcoupons.com, savvycalifornia.com etc.
